title: Rooting and sucking reflexes are well developed
description: The baby's mouth will instinctively suckle when stroking cheek or palm.

title: Immature Tongue Movements
description: Swallowing reflex and tongue movements are immature; inability to move food to the back of the mouth.

title: Fingers reflexively close
description: The baby's fingers will reflexively close around objects placed in their hand

title: Landau Reflex
description: When baby is held in a prone (face down) position, the head is held upright and legs are fully extended.

title: Grasps with entire hand
description: Grasps with entire hand; strength insufficient to hold items. Holds hands in an open or semi-open position.

title: Larger & Jerky movements
description: Movements are large and jerky.

title: Raises head and upper body when face down
description: Raises head and upper body on arms when in a prone position.

title: Turns head side to side when face up
description: Turns head side to side when in a supine (face up) position;can not hold head up and line with the body.

title: Upper body more active
description: Upper body parts are more active: clasps hands above face, waves arms about, reaches for objects.

title: Blinking reflex is well established
description: Baby will blink if an object comes close to their eyes

title: Sucking Reflex
description: Sucking reflex becomes voluntary

title: Moro Reflex
description: Reacts when startled by strecthing out arms and flexing legs

title: Protective Reflex
description: When lowered suddenly, infant throws out arms as a protective measure.

title: Swallowing Reflex
description: Swallowing reflex appears and allows infant to move solid foods from front of mouth to the back for swallowing.

title: Pincer Grip
description: Picks up objects using finger and thumb (pincer grip).

title: Reaches with both arms
description: Reaches for objects with both arms simultaneously

title: Reaches with one hand
description: Reaches for objects with one hand or the other

title: Palmar Grasp
description: Transfers objects from one hand to the other; grasps object using entire hand (palmar grasp).

title: Handles Objects and Puts Everything in Mouth
description: Handles, shakes, and pounds objects; puts everything in mouth.

title: Holds Bottle
description: Able to hold bottle.

title: Sits without support
description: Sits alone without support, holding head erect, back straightened, and arms propped forward for support

title: Pulls self into crawling position
description: Pulls self into a crawling position by raising up on arms and drawing knees up beneath the body; rocks back and forth, but generally does not move forward.

title: Lifts head when on back
description: Lifts head when placed on back.

title: Rolls over
description: Can roll over from back or stomach position.

title: Scoots backwards
description: May accidentally begin scooting backwards when placed on stomach; soon will begin to crawl forward.

title: Looks for fallen objects
description: Looks for fallen objects by 7 months

title: Plays "Peek-a-Boo"
description: Plays ‘peek-a-boo’ games

title: Cognitive?
description: Cannot understand “no” or “danger”

title: Reaches towards offered object
description: Reaches with one hand leading to grasp an offered object or toy.

title: Transfers objects from one hand to another
description: Manipulates objects, transferring them from one hand to the other.

title: Pokes new objects with finger
description: Explores new objects by poking with one finger.

title: Deliberate Pincer Grasp
description: Uses deliberate pincer grasp to pick up small objects, toys, and finger foods.

title: Stacks objects
description: Stacks objects; also places objects inside one another.

title: Drops or throws objects
description: Releases objects or toys by dropping or throwing; cannot intentionally put an object down.

title: Pulls self to standing position
description: Beginning to pull self to a standing position.

title: Begins to stand alone
description: Beginning to stand alone, leaning on furniture for support

title: Sidesteps while supported standing
description: Moves around obstacles by side-stepping.

title: Balanced sitting
description: Has good balance when sitting; can shift positions without falling.

title: Creeps
description: Creeps on hands and knees

title: Crawls up and down stairs
description: Crawls up and down stairs.

title: Walks with adult support
description: Walks with adult support, holding onto adult's hand; may begin to walk alone.

title: Watches immediate environment
description: Watches people, objects, and activities in the immediate environment.

title: Responds to hearing tests
description: Responds to hearing tests (voice localization); however, loses interest quickly and, therefore, may be difficult to test formally.

title: Cognitive?
description: Follows simple instructions.

title: Reaches for visible items out of reach
description: Reaches for toys that are out of reach but visible

title: Recognizes objects in reverse
description: Recognizes objects in reverse

title: Intentionally drops objects
description: Drops thing intentionally and repeats and watches object

title: Imitates activities
description: Imitates activities like playing drum

title: Begins to use expressive language
description: Begins to develop expressive rather than receptive language- child actually responding to what is said to him instead of only receiving and watching the interaction.

title: Skillful crawling
description: Crawls skillfully and quickly.

title: Stands alone
description: Stands alone with feet spread apart, legs stiffened, and arms extended for support.

title: Gets to feet unaided
description: Gets to feet unaided.

title: Walks unassisted
description: Most children walk unassisted near the end of this period; falls often; not always able to maneuver around obstacles, such as furniture or toys.

title: Lowers self to floor
description: Uses furniture to lower self to floor; collapses backwards into a sitting position or falls forward on hands and then sits.

title: Pushes or Pulls toys while walking
description: Enjoys pushing or pulling toys while walking.

title: Throws objects with more deliberate aim
description: Repeatedly picks up objects and throws them; direction becomes more deliberate.

title: Runs, but has difficulty stopping
description: Attempts to run; has difficulty stopping and usually just drops to the floor.

title: Crawls up stairs on all fours
description: Crawls up stairs on all fours; goes down stairs in same position.

title: Sits in small chair
description: Sits in a small chair.

title: Carries toys
description: Carries toys from place to place.

title: Scribbles with whole arm
description: Enjoys crayons and markers for scribbling; uses whole-arm movement.

title: Helps feed self
description: Helps feed self; enjoys holding spoon (often upside down) and drinking from a glass or cup; not always accurate in getting utensils into mouth; frequent spills should be expected.

title: Helps turn pages in book
description: Helps turn pages in book.

title: Stacks two to six objects
description: Stacks two to six objects per day.

title: Walks around obstacles
description: Can walk around obstacles and walk more erect

title: Squats while playing
description: Squats for long periods while playing.

title: Climbs stairs without alternating feet
description: Climbs stairs unassisted (but not with alternating feet).

title: Balances on one foot
description: Balances on one foot (for a few moments), jumps up and down, but may fall.

title: Potty Training
description: Often achieves toilet training during this year (depending on child's physical and neurological development) although accidents should still be expected; the child will indicate readiness for toilet training.

title: Throws large objects underhand
description: Throws large ball underhand without losing balance.

title: Holds smaller items with one hand
description: Holds small cup or tumbler in one hand.

title: Unbuttons large buttons
description: Unbuttons large buttons; unzips large zippers.

title: Opens doors with doorknobs
description: Opens doors by turning doorknobs.

title: Scribbles with crayon in fist
description: Grasps large crayon with fist; scribbles.

title: Climbs up into chairs
description: Climbs up on chair, turns, and sits down.

title: Stacks four to six objects
description: Stacks four to six objects on top of one another.

title: Propels wheeled toys with feet
description: Uses feet to propel wheeled riding toys.

title: Climbs stairs with alternating feet
description: Walks up and down stairs unassisted, using alternating feet; may jump from bottom step, landing on both feet.

title: Balances on one foot
description: Can momentarily balance on one foot.

title: Kicks larger objects
description: Can kick big ball-shaped objects.

title: Eats with minimal assistance
description: Needs minimal assistance eating.

title: Jumps on spot
description: Jumps on the spot.

title: Pedals small tricycle
description: Pedals a small tricycle.

title: Throws overhand
description: Throws a ball overhand; aim and distance are limited.

title: Catches with both arms
description: Catches a large bounced ball with both arms extended.

title: Swings on swing
description: Enjoys swinging on a swing.

title: Uses controlled strokes when drawing
description: Shows improved control of crayons or markers; uses vertical, horizontal and circular strokes.

title: Uses two fingers when drawing
description: Holds crayon or marker between first two fingers and thumb (tripod grasp), not in a fist as earlier.

title: Turns pages of book
description: Can turn pages of a book one at a time

title: Builds with blocks
description: Enjoys building with blocks.

title: Builds tower with eight or more blocks
description: Builds a tower of eight or more blocks.

title: Pounds, rolls and squeezes clay
description: Enjoys playing with clay; pounds, rolls, and squeezes it.

title: Shows slight hand dominance
description: May begin to show hand dominance.

title: Carries liquid with little spillage
description: Carries a container of liquid, such as a cup of milk or bowl of water, without much spilling; pours liquid from pitcher into another container.

title: Manipulates buttons and zippers on clothing
description: Manipulates large buttons and zippers on clothing.

title: Washes and dries hands
description: Washes and dries hands

title: Brushes own teeth
description: Brushes own teeth, but not thoroughly

title: Can control bladder
description: Usually achieves complete bladder control during this time.

title: Walks straight line
description: Walks a straight line (tape or chalk line on the floor).

title: Hops on one foot
description: Hops on one foot.

title: Avoids obstacles when pedaling toy
description: Pedals and steers a wheeled toy with confidence; turns corners, avoids obstacles and oncoming "traffic."

title: Climbs ladders and playground equipment
description: Climbs ladders, trees, playground equipment.

title: Jumps over taller objects
description: Jumps over objects 12 to 15 cm (5 to 6 in) high; lands with both feet together.

title: Runs with control
description: Runs, starts, stops, and moves around obstacles with ease.

title: Throws overhand with increased aim
description: Throws a ball overhand; distance and aim improving.

title: Builds tower with ten or more blocks
description: Builds a tower with ten or more blocks.

title: Uses clay to create shapes and objects
description: Forms shapes and objects out of clay: cookies, snakes, simple animals.

title: Draws shapes and letters
description: Reproduces some shapes and letters.

title: Draws with tripod grasp
description: Holds a crayon or marker using a tripod grasp.

title: Draws with purpose
description: Paints and draws with purpose; may have an idea in mind, but often has problems implementing it so calls the creation something else.

title: Increased accuracy at hitting toys with hammer
description: Becomes more accurate at hitting nails and pegs with hammer.

title: Threads wooden beads on string
description: Threads small wooden beads on a string.

title: Runs in circle
description: Can run in a circle

title: Walks backwards
description: Walks backwards, toe to heel.

title: Climbs stairs with alternating feet
description: Walks unassisted up and down stairs, alternating feet.

title: Somersaults
description: May learn to turn somersaults (should be taught the right way in order to avoid injury).

title: Touches toes without bending knees
description: Can touch toes without flexing knees.

title: Walks a balance beam
description: Walks a balance beam.

title: Skips with alternate feet
description: Learns to skip using alternative feet.

title: Catches ball from short distance
description: Catches a ball thrown from 1 m (3.3 ft) away.

title: Skillfully steers wheeled toy
description: Rides a tricycle or wheeled toy with speed and skillful steering; some children learning to ride bicycles, usually with training wheels.

title: Jumps multiple times without falling
description: Jumps or hops forward ten times in a row without falling.

title: Balances on one foot for longer duration
description: Balances on either foot with good control for ten seconds.

title: Builds 3D structure
description: Builds three-dimensional structures with small cubes by copying from a picture or model.

title: Writes shapes and letters
description: Reproduces many shapes and letters: square, triangle, A, I, O, U, C, H, L, T.

title: Uses pencil with control
description: Demonstrates fair control of pencil or marker; may begin to color within the lines.

title: Uses scissors with limited precision
description: Cuts on the line with scissors (not perfectly).

title: Established hand dominance
description: Hand dominance is fairly well established

title: Cognitive?
description: Often has an imaginary friend

title: Greater control with movements
description: Gains greater control over large and fine motor skills; movements are more precise and deliberate, though some clumsiness persists.

title: Enjoys vigorous play
description: Enjoys vigorous running, jumping, climbing, and throwing etc.

title: Active
description: Has trouble staying still.

title: Increased attention span
description: Span of attention increases; works at tasks for longer periods of time

title: Cognitive?
description: Can concentrate effort but not always consistently.

title: Cognitive?
description: Understands time (today, tomorrow, yesterday) and simple motion (things go faster than others).

title: Cognitive?
description: Recognizes seasons and major activities done in the times.

title: Cognitive?
description: Has fun with problem solving and sorting activities like stacking, puzzles and mazes

title: Cognitive?
description: Enjoys the challenge of puzzles, counting and sorting activities, paper-and-pencil mazes, and games that involve matching letters and words with pictures.

title: Recognizes some words by sight
description: Recognizes some words by sight; attempts to sound out words

title: Increased reading level
description: In some cases the child may be reading well.

title: Increased dexterity
description: functioning which facilitates learning to ride a bicycle, swim, swing a bat, or kick a ball.

title: Cognitive?
description: Making things is enjoyed.

title: Reading
description: Reverses or confuse certain letters: b/d, p/g, g/q, t/f.

title: Draws traced objects
description: Able to trace objects.

title: Uses scissors to cut shapes
description: Folds and cuts paper into simple shapes.

title: Ties shoelaces
description: Can Tie Laces, string (like shoes).

title: Enjoys object-hiding activites
description: Enjoys object-hiding activities.

title: Remembers where objects have been hidden
description: Early in this period, the child always searches in the same location for a hidden object (if the child has watched the hiding of an object). Later, the child will search in several locations.

title: Passes objects between hands when offered additional item
description: Passes toy to other hand when offered a second object (referred to as "crossing the midline" – an important neurological development).

title: Manages holding three or more objects by placing original item aside
description: Manages three to four objects by setting an object aside (on lap or floor) when presented with a new toy.

title: Decrease in putting objects in mouth
description: Puts toys in mouth less often.

title: Enjoys picture books
description: Enjoys looking at picture books.

title: Understands functional relationships of objects
description: Demonstrates understanding of functional relationships (objects that belong together): Puts spoon in bowl and then uses spoon as if eating; places teacup on saucer and sips from cup; tries to make doll stand up.

title: Shows/Offers toys to other people
description: Shows or offers toy to another person to look at.

title: Can name everyday objects
description: Names many everyday objects.

title: Increased spatial understanding
description: Shows increasing understanding of spatial and form discrimination: puts all pegs in a pegboard; places three geometric shapes in large formboard or puzzle.

title: Fills and empties containers
description: Places several small items (blocks, clothespins, cereal pieces) in a container or bottle and then dumps them out.

title: Attempts to use mechanical objects
description: Tries to make mechanical objects work after watching someone else do so.

title: Begins to imitate facial expressions
description: Responds with some facial movement, but cannot truly imitate facial expression.

title: Increased eye-hand coordination
description: Eye–hand movements better coordinated; can put objects together, take them apart; fit large pegs into pegboard.

title: Uses objects for other purposes than intended
description: Begins to use objects for purposes other than intended (may push a block around as a boat).

title: Can classify objects by one dimension
description: Does simple classification tasks based on single dimension (separates toy dinosaurs from toy cars).

title: Interested in figuring out environmental situations
description: Seems fascinated by, or engrossed in, figuring out situations: where the tennis ball rolled, where the dog went, what caused a particular noise.

title: Increased attention span
description: Attends to self-selected activities for longer periods of time.

title: Discovers cause and effect of actions
description: Discovering cause and effect: squeezing the cat makes her scratch.

title: Understands object permanence
description: Knows where familiar persons should be; notes their absence; finds a hidden object by looking in last hiding place first. (This is what Piaget termed object permanence, which usually occurs during the sensorimotor stage of Piaget's childhood theory of cognitive development)

title: Names familiar objects
description: Names familiar objects.

title: Able to express location of pain
description: Recognizes, expresses, and locates pain.

title: Uses magical thinking
description: Expected to use "magical thinking", such as believing a toy bear is a real bear.

title: Recounts non-present objects and events
description: Tells about objects and events not immediately present (this is both a cognitive and linguistic advance).

title: Increased curiosity about the world
description: Expresses more curiosity about the world.

title: Listens attentively to age-appropriate stories
description: Listens attentively to age-appropriate stories.

title: Provides relevant comments on stories
description: Makes relevant comments during stories, especially those that relate to home and family events.

title: Reads books by explaining pictures
description: Likes to look at books and may pretend to "read" to others or explain pictures.

title: Enjoys guessing stories
description: Enjoys stories with riddles, guessing, and "suspense."

title: Speaks in an understandable manner
description: Speech is understandable most of the time.

title: Uses expanded noun phrases
description: Produces expanded noun phrases: "big, brown dog."

title: Creates verbs and plural nouns
description: Produces verbs with "ing" endings; uses "-s" to indicate more than one; often puts "-s" on already pluralized forms: geeses, mices.

title: Indicates negative with language
description: Indicates negatives by inserting "no" or "not" before a simple noun or verb phrase: "Not baby."

title: Answers "What?", "Where?" and "Why?" questions
description: Answers "What are you doing?", "What is this?", and "Where?" questions dealing with familiar objects and events.

title: Understands rhyme words
description: Can recognize that certain words sound similar

title: Can recognize about twenty uppercase letters
description: Names eighteen to twenty uppercase letters.

title: Writes several letters and name
description: Writes several letters and sometimes their name.

title: Reads simple books
description: A few children are beginning to read simple books, such as alphabet books with only a few words per page and many pictures.

title: Interest in how things grown and operate
description: Likes stories about how things grow and how things operate.

title: Uses silly language
description: Delights in wordplay, creating silly Language.

title: Understands comparitive speech
description: Understands the concepts of "tallest," "biggest," "same," and "more"; selects the picture that has the "most houses" or the "biggest dogs."

title: Counts to 20 or more
description: Rote counts to 20 or more.

title: Understands sequence of daily events
description: Understands the sequence of daily events: "When we get up in the morning, we get dressed, have breakfast, brush our teeth, and go to school."

title: Recognizes missing objects in pictures
description: When looking at pictures, can recognize and identify missing puzzle parts (of person, car, animal).

title: Increased story-telling ability
description: Very good storytellers.

title: Can count one to seven objects
description: Counts 1 to 7 objects out loud, but not always in order

title: Follows directions up to three steps
description: follows two to three step directions given individually or in a group

title: Adds "ed" to verbs
description: may put the "ed" on the end of words such as "I goed outside and I played."

title: Builds shapes from other shapes
description: Forms rectangle from two triangular cuts.

title: Builds more complex objects with blocks
description: Builds steps with set of small blocks.

title: Understands shape and size
description: Understands concept of same shape, same size.

title: Sorts objects by two dimensions
description: Sorts objects on the basis of two dimensions, such as color and form.

title: Classifies objects by common feature
description: Sorts a variety of objects so that all things in the group have a single common feature (classification skill: all are food items or boats or animals).

title: Sorts objects in order
description: Understands the concepts of smallest and shortest; places objects in order from shortest to tallest, smallest to largest.

title: Identifies objects by serial position
description: Identifies objects with specified serial position: first, second, last.

title: Counts above 20
description: Rote counts to 20 and above; many children count to 100.

title: Reads numbers
description: Recognizes numerals from 1 to 10.

title: Understands concept of "less than"
description: Understands the concepts of less than: "Which bowl has less water?"

title: Understands descriptive terms
description: Understands the terms dark, light, and early: "I got up early, before anyone else. It was still dark."

title: Relates daily schedule to time on clock
description: Relates clock time to daily schedule: "Time to turn on TV when the little hand points to 5."

title: Able to tell time by the hour
description: Some children can tell time on the hour: five o'clock, two o'clock.

title: Understand the concept of a calendar
description: Knows what a calendar is for.

title: Able to count coins
description: Recognizes and identifies coins; beginning to count and save money.

title: Knows the alphabet
description: Many children know the alphabet and names of upper- and lowercase letters.

title: Understand the concept of "half"
description: Understands the concept of half; can say how many pieces an object has when it's been cut in half.

title: Ask innumberable questions
description: Asks innumerable questions: Why? What? Where? When? How?

title: Interest in learning new things
description: Eager to learn new things.

title: Produces "jargon"
description: Produces considerable "jargon": puts words and sounds together into speech-like (inflected) patterns.

title: Holophrastic Speech
description: Holophrastic speech: uses one word to convey an entire thought; meaning depends on the inflection ("me" may be used to request more cookies or a desire to feed self).

title: Telegraphic Speech
description: Produces two-word phrases to express a complete thought (telegraphic speech): "More cookie," "Daddy bye-bye."

title: Follows simple directions
description: Follows simple directions, "Give Daddy the cup."

title: Responds to questions by pointing
description: When asked, will point to familiar persons, animals, and toys.

title: Points to three body parts when named
description: Identifies three body parts if someone names them: "Show me your nose (toe, ear)."

title: Verbally indicates desired objects and activities
description: Indicates a few desired objects and activities by name: "Bye-bye," "cookie"; verbal request is often accompanied by an insistent gesture.

title: Responds verbally and with head movement to "yes" or "no" questions
description: Responds to simple questions with "yes" or "no" and appropriate head movement.

title: Speech is 25%-50% intelligible
description: Speech is 25 to 50 percent intelligible during this period.

title: Locates familiar objects on request
description: Locates familiar objects on request (if child knows location of objects).

title: Uses five to fifty words
description: Acquires and uses five to fifty words; typically these are words that refer to animals, food, and toys.

title: Directs adult attention with gestures
description: Uses gestures, such as pointing or pulling, to direct adult attention.

title: Tries to join rhymes and songs
description: Enjoys rhymes and songs; tries to join in.

title: Aware of reciprocal aspects of conversational exchanges
description: Seems aware of reciprocal (back and forth) aspects of conversational exchanges; some turn-taking in other kinds of vocal exchanges, such as making and imitating sounds.

title: Participates while being read to
description: Enjoys participating while being read to.

title: Uses language to get desired response
description: Realizes language is effective for getting desired responses.

title: Uses fifty to three hundred words
description: Uses fifty to three-hundred words; vocabulary continuously increasing.
Has broken the linguistic code; in other words, much of a two-year-old's talk has meaning to him or her.
Receptive language is more developed than expressive language; most two-year olds understand significantly more than they can talk about.
Utters three- and four-word statements; uses conventional word order to form more complete sentences.
Refers to self as "me" or sometimes "I" rather than by name: "Me go bye-bye"; has no trouble verbalizing "mine."
Expresses negative statements by tacking on a negative word such as "no" or "not": "Not more milk."
Uses some plurals.
Some stammering and other dysfluencies are common.
Speech is as much as 65 to 70 percent intelligible.
Is able to verbalize needs.
Asks a lot of questions.
Shows signs of empathy and caring: comforts another child if hurt or frightened; appears to sometimes be overly affectionate in offering hugs and kisses to children
Continues to use physical aggression if frustrated or angry (for some children, this is more exaggerated than for others); Physical aggression usually lessens as verbal skills improve.
Temper tantrums likely to peak during this year; extremely difficult to reason with during a tantrum.
Impatient; finds it difficult to wait or take turns.
Enjoys "helping" with household chores; imitates everyday activities: may try to toilet train a stuffed animal, feed a doll.
Bossy with parents and caregivers; orders them around, makes demands, expects immediate compliance from adults.

Watches and imitates the play of other children, but seldom interacts directly; plays near others, often choosing similar toys and activities (parallel play);[6] solitary play is often simple and repetitive.[7]
Offers toys to other children, but is usually possessive of playthings; still tends to hoard toys.
Making choices is difficult; wants it both ways.
Often defiant; shouting "no" becomes automatic.
Ritualistic; wants everything "just so"; routines carried out exactly as before; belongings placed "where they belong."
Uses the prepositions "on," "in," and "under."
Uses possessives consistently: "hers," "theirs," "baby's."
Answers "Whose?", "Who?", "Why?", and "How many?"
Produces elaborate sentence structures: "The cat ran under the house before I could see what color it was."
Speech is almost entirely intelligible.
Begins to use the past tense of verbs correctly: "Mommy closed the door," "Daddy went to work."
Refers to activities, events, objects, and people that are not present.
Changes tone of voice and sentence structure to adapt to listener's level of understanding: To baby brother, "Milk gone?" To Mother, "Did the baby drink all of his milk?"
States first and last name, gender, siblings' names, and sometimes own telephone number.
Answers appropriately when asked what to do if tired, cold, or hungry. Recites and sings simple songs like mangoes and rhymes.
Outgoing; friendly; overly enthusiastic at times.
Moods change rapidly and unpredictably; laughing one minute, crying the next; may throw tantrum over minor frustrations (a block structure that will not balance); sulk over being left out.
Imaginary playmates or companions are common; holds conversations and shares strong emotions with this invisible friend.
Boasts, exaggerates, and "bends" the truth with made-up stories or claims of boldness; tests the limits with "bathroom" talk.
Cooperates with others; participates in group activities.
Shows pride in accomplishments; seeks frequent adult approval.
Often appears selfish; not always able to take turns or to understand taking turns under some conditions; tattles on other children.
Insists on trying to do things independently, but may get so frustrated as to verge on tantrums when problems arise: paint that drips, paper airplane that will not fold right.
Enjoys role-playing and make-believe activities.
Relies (most of the time) on verbal rather than Physical aggression; may yell angrily rather than hit to make a point; threatens: "You can't come to my birthday party"
Name-calling and taunting are often used as ways of excluding other children.
Establishes close relationships with playmates; beginning to have "best" friends.
Vocabulary of 1,500 words plus.
Tells a familiar story while looking at pictures in a book.
Defines simple words by function: a ball is to bounce; a bed is to sleep in.
Identifies and names four to eight colours.
Recognizes the humor in simple jokes; makes up jokes and riddles.
Produces sentences with five to seven words; much longer sentences are not unusual.
States the name of own city or town, birthday, and parents' names.
Answers telephone appropriately; calls person to phone or takes a brief message
Speech is almost entirely grammatically correct.
Uses "would" and "could" appropriately.
Uses past tense of irregular verbs consistently: "went," "caught," "swam."
Uses past-tense inflection (-ed) appropriately to mark regular verbs: "jumped," "rained," "washed."
Enjoys and often has one or two focus friendships.
Plays cooperatively (can lapse), is generous, takes turns, shares toys.
Participates in group play and shared activities with other children; suggests imaginative and elaborate play ideas.
Shows affection and caring towards others especially those “below” them or in pain
Generally subservient to parent or caregiver requests.
Needs comfort and reassurance from adults but is less open to comfort.
Has better self-control over swings of emotions.
Likes entertaining people and making them laugh.
Boasts about accomplishments.
Often has an imaginary friend
Can identify right and left hands fairly consistently.
Holds onto positive beliefs involving the unexplainable (magic or fantasy)
Arrives at some understanding about death and dying; expresses fear that parents may die.
Talks a lot.
Loves telling jokes and riddles; often, the humor is far from subtle.
Experiments with slang and profanity and finds it funny.
Enthusiastic and inquisitive about surroundings and everyday events.
Able to carry on adult-like conversations; asks many questions.
Learns 5 to 10 words a day; vocabulary of 10,000–14,000.
Uses appropriate verb tenses, word order, and sentence structure.
Uses language rather than tantrums or physical aggression to express displeasure: "That's mine! Give it back, you dummy."
Talks self through steps required in simple problem-solving situations (though the "logic" may be unclear to adults).
Has mood swings towards primary caregiver depending on the day
Friendship with parent is less depended on but still needs closeness and nurturing.
Anxious to please; needs and seeks adult approval, reassurance, and praise; may complain excessively about minor hurts to gain more attention.
Often can't view the world from another’s point of view
Self-perceived failure can make the child easily disappointed and frustrated.
Can't handle things not going their own way
Does not understand ethical behavior or moral standards especially when doing things that have not been given rules
Understands when he or she has been thought to be "bad"; values are based on others' enforced values.
May be increasingly fearful of the unknown like things in the dark, noises, and animals.
